rounds.response:
I hold A♠ K♥ – one of the very best starting hands in Hold’em. After my raise to 80, villain has three-bet to 240. I have to decide: fold, call, or shove. 

- Pot odds: I’d have to call 160 more for a 320 pot ⇒ exactly 2-to-1.  
- Effective stacks: Villain has 770 behind, I have 910, so we’re both fairly deep for this level.  
- Hand strength: AK is a monster here and crushes most villain three-bet ranges heads-up.

Folding is clearly wrong with AK. Calling keeps villain’s range wide and preserves all post-flop play, so no need to 4-bet jam yet with deep stacks.

[Call]

rounds.response:
I am heads-up versus Player 1 and we are on the river.  The pot is 480 chips, both of us have checked both flop and turn, and no bet is currently facing me.  My hand is A♠ K♥, giving me two-pair (aces and fours) with a King kicker.  The only better made hand at this point is a set of eights, and since I was the three-bettor pre-flop it’s entirely possible my opponent is holding something like 8-7s, 8-6s or 8-8, but the line he took—simply calling the 3-bet and then checking back both flop and turn—removes a lot of 8-x combos because most players continuation-bet 8♣ 4♥ or 8♣ A♣ boards with something like A-8 or 8-9 suited.

Given the pot size (480 chips) and my stack (750), a bet in the ~½-pot to ⅔-pot region is both value-heavy and logically consistent line.  A 240-chip bet (exactly half pot) gives my opponent 3-to-1 odds and should get called by any ace weaker than AK, plus occasional bluff-catchers like 8-7s, 7-7 or 9-9 which “improve” to an ace-high one-pair or trip fours on the river.

[Action]
[Bet 240]

rounds.response:
Let’s size up the situation.

Pot: 120  
Effective stack P1: 550  
My position: first-to-act (small-blind)

Board: 8♥ J♠ Q♣  
Our hand: 6♦ K♦ – we have exactly the Broadway draw: T9 makes the nut straight, our K gives us the top-end gut-shot plus an overcard to any non-KQJ hand. Against a random BB defending range we probably have the required equity for a small double-barrel, but with only 550 chips behind a flop c-bet that risks another raise is awkward.

A standard c-bet of roughly 60 % pot (≈ 75) puts villain in the danger zone—any further raise threatens his last chips and any flat still leaves turn/river EQR (effective equity realization) concerns for him. We also block some single-K hands that might call once.

Therefore:

[Bet 75]
